metadata.sermon_title: Sixth Sunday After Pentecost / Second Sunday After Pentecost
metadata.notes: The text covers two separate homiletic reflections focusing on the Trinity and the nature of sin/forgiveness.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher utilizes a 'Soft CP' approach. While not shouting, the preacher insists on the label 'miserable offender' and critiques the modern church for removing 'there is no health in us.' This creates a dogmatic requirement for self-abasement as a prerequisite for grace.
quotes: the depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'
The removal of this line has robbed us of a powerful buttress...

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is strong in the first section, using the imagery of a desperate parent to illustrate God's love. It is supportive but leans slightly toward creating a 'Child' dependency on the 'Parental' God.
quotes: You would make a complete fool of yourself if you thought it might get your child’s attention.
the love that persists in breaking through our resistance...

adult.analysis: The preacher uses historical context and linguistic comparisons (Adult data processing) to explain the Trinitarian formula. However, the Adult is often bypassed in favor of emotional appeals to the 'Child' ego state regarding guilt and rescue.
quotes: Now, therefore, we are ready to see that Paul was not being perfunctory after all.
Compare this benediction at the end of 2 Corinthians with those in his other letters.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly invites the listener into the Adapted Child position—specifically the 'Miserable/Guilty Child.' It suggests that the only way to be 'saved' is to first accept a state of total 'unhealth' and 'wretchedness.'
quotes: none of us can hold up our heads.
there is something fundamentally, drastically, terribly wrong with all of us.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a mention of 'joyous and liberating knowledge,' but it is a secondary byproduct of the Adapted Child's submission, rather than a primary expression of spontaneous Free Child energy.
quotes: beautiful, ecstatic imagery, thinks of himself as a watchman...

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher speaks as the authoritative Parent (interpreting the 'true' meaning of the prayer book and scripture) to the listener's Child. The listener is encouraged to agree with their own 'wretchedness' to receive the Parent's comfort.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: The social transaction is 'I am teaching you about God's love' (A->A). The psychological transaction is 'You are sick/bad, and only my message can provide the cure' (P->C).
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the definition of mercy: it requires the listener to maintain a low self-image ('no health in us') to maximize the 'merit' of the giver.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch (Redemption)

formula_g_analysis.con: The promise of 'the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ' and 'infinite mercy.'
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's inherent sense of inadequacy or 'messed-up lives.'
formula_g_analysis.switch: The insistence that one must first admit they are a 'miserable offender' with 'no health' in them.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A feeling of relief that is dependent on continued self-deprecation.

evidence_quotes: The less we deserve, the more merit is in his bounty.

detected_games.name: ITHY (I'm Only Trying To Help You)

formula_g_analysis.con: Preacher offers the 'path of life' through confession.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Labeling the listener as part of a 'vast primordial catastrophe.'
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The preacher maintains the role of the one who knows the 'one thing we really need to know.'

evidence_quotes: It seems that there are many who do not want to hear that we are 'miserable offenders,' and yet those who hear it and believe it find this confession to be the path of life.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High; the preacher presents the 'formula' for grace and the 'apostolic blessing' as the solution to the listener's 'self-destruction.'
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low-Medium; manifests in the critique of those who 'do not want to hear' the truth of their own misery.
preacher_roles.victim: Low; briefly adopts Paul's 'agonized' position to build empathy.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim. The congregation is framed as 'anorexic,' 'hooked on drugs,' or 'miserable offenders' who cannot 'hold up their heads.'
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Limited. The 'escape' offered is not toward Adult autonomy, but toward a more 'grateful' dependency on the Rescuer/God.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is a classic example of 'High Parent' homiletics. While theologically rich in its description of the Trinity, it relies heavily on the psychological 'put-down' to make the 'lift-up' feel effective. By insisting on the phrase 'there is no health in us,' the preacher reinforces a shame-based identity (Adapted Child) as the only valid entry point for spirituality. This creates a cycle where the listener must feel 'bad' to feel 'God.'
strengths: Strong use of metaphor (the desperate parent) to explain complex concepts.
Adult-level historical analysis of Pauline benedictions.
areas_for_improvement: Heavy reliance on 'shame-logic' to highlight grace.
Pushes the listener into a permanent 'Victim' role within the Drama Triangle.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try addressing the congregation as 'Adults' who are capable of choosing the good, rather than 'Children' who are fundamentally 'unhealthy.' Frame grace as an empowerment for autonomy (Free Child) rather than just a rescue from wretchedness (Adapted Child).
